1:
Be yourself. Everyone else is taken.
-Oscar Wilde
2:
Even the darkest night will end and sun will rise.
-Victor Hugo
3:
Beware; for I am fearless, and therefore powerful.
-Mary Shelley
4:
I would always rather be happy than dignified.
-Charlotte Brontë
5:
Always forgive your enemies; nothing annoys them so much.
-Oscar Wilde
6:
Skill to do comes of doing.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
7:
Nature provides exceptions to every rule.
-Margaret Fuller
8:
The way to right wrongs is to turn the light of truth upon them.
-IDA B. WELLS-BARNETT
9:
Our greatest glory is not in never failing, but in rising up every time we fail.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
10:
Man is least himself when he talks in his own person. Give him a mask, and he will tell the truth.
-Oscar Wilde
11:
Simplicity is the glory of expression.
-Walt Whitman
12:
Today a reader, tomorrow a leader.
— Margaret Fuller
13:
I am not afraid of storms, for I am learning how to sail my ship.
- Louisa May Alcott
14:
The purpose of life is not to be happy. It is to be useful, to be honorable, to be compassionate, to have it make some difference that you have lived and lived well.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
15:
Life isn’t about finding yourself; it’s about creating yourself. So live the life you imagined.
-Henry David Thoreau
16:
Earth has no sorrow that earth cannot heal.
-John Muir
17:
I can resist everything except temptation.
-Oscar Wilde
18:
Live in the sunshine, swim the sea, drink the wild air.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
19:
Not I nor anyone else can travel that road for you. You must travel it by yourself. It is not far. It is within reach. Perhaps you have been on it since you were born, and did not know. Perhaps it is everywhere – on water and land.
-Walt Whitman
20:
If you have knowledge, let others light their candles in it.
— Margaret Fuller
21:
A hero is no braver than an ordinary man, but he is brave five minutes longer.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
22:
Hope is the thing with feathers That perches in the soul And sings the tune without the words And never stops at all.
-Emily Dickinson
23:
Life is my college. May I graduate well, and earn some honors.
- Louisa May Alcott
24:
Without ambition one starts nothing. Without work one finishes nothing. The prize will not be sent to you. You have to win it.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
25:
It is better to fail in originality than to succeed in imitation.
-Herman Melville
26:
The language of friendship is not words but meanings.
-Henry David Thoreau
27:
Give me the splendid, silent sun with all his beams full-dazzling.
-Walt Whitman
28:
Youth smiles without any reason. It is one of its chiefest charms.
Thomas Gray
29:
I know not all that may be coming, but be it what it will, I'll go to it laughing.
-Herman Melville
30:
Nothing great was ever achieved without enthusiasm.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
31:
Forever is composed of nows.
-Emily Dickinson
32:
He who believes is strong; he who doubts is weak. Strong convictions precede great actions.
- Louisa May Alcott
33:
For every minute you remain angry, you give up sixty seconds of peace of mind.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
34:
Nature provides exceptions to every rule.
— Margaret Fuller
35:
The art of art, the glory of expression and the sunshine of the light of letters, is simplicity.
-Walt Whitman
36:
Life is a journey, not a destination.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
37:
Of all the paths you take in life, make sure a few of them are dirt.
-John Muir
38:
What lies behind us and what lies ahead of us are tiny matters compared to what lives within us.
-Henry David Thoreau
39:
Very early, I knew that the only object in life was to grow.
— Margaret Fuller
40:
A smile is the chosen vehicle of all ambiguities.
-Herman Melville
41:
It's amazing how lovely common things become, if one only knows how to look at them.
- Louisa May Alcott
42:
It is not the length of life, but the depth.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
43:
Nature’s peace will flow into you as sunshine into trees.
-John Muir
44:
I discover myself on the verge of a usual mistake.
-Walt Whitman
45:
What lies behind you and what lies in front of you, pales in comparison to what lies inside of you.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
46:
A man's face is his autobiography. A woman's face is her work of fiction.
-Oscar Wilde
47:
I accept the universe!
— Margaret Fuller
48:
When it is dark enough, you can see the stars.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
49:
Most men lead lives of quiet desperation and go to the grave with the song still in them.
-Henry David Thoreau
50:
The power of finding beauty in the humblest things makes home happy and life lovely.
- Louisa May Alcott
51:
It is not down on any map; true places never are.
-Herman Melville
52:
We don’t read and write poetry because it’s cute. We read and write poetry because we are members of the human race. And the human race is filled with passion. So medicine, law, business, engineering… these are noble pursuits and necessary to sustain life. But poetry, beauty, romance, love… these are what we stay alive for.
-Walt Whitman
53:
Wilderness is a necessity… there must be places for human beings to satisfy their souls.
-John Muir
54:
Make the most of yourself….for that is all there is of you.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
55:
That it will never come again is what makes life so sweet.
-Emily Dickinson
56:
One touch of nature makes the whole world kin.
-William Shakespeare
57:
He who is not everyday conquering some fear has not learned the secret of life.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
58:
I'd rather take coffee than compliments just now.
- Louisa May Alcott
59:
Pain has no effect but to steal some of my time.
— Margaret Fuller
60:
I cannot remember the books I’ve read any more than the meals I have eaten; even so, they have made me.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
61:
Do not lose hold of your dreams or aspirations. For if you do, you may still exist but you have ceased to live.
-Henry David Thoreau
62:
As for me, I am tormented with an everlasting itch for things remote. I love to sail forbidden seas, and land on barbarous coasts.
-Herman Melville
63:
Battles are lost in the same spirit in which they are won.
-Walt Whitman
64:
Poetry is thoughts that breathe, and words that burn.
Thomas Gray
65:
I've got the key to my castle in the air, but whether I can unlock the door remains to be seen.
- Louisa May Alcott
66:
Be silly. Be honest. Be kind.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
67:
True friends stab you in the front.
-Oscar Wilde
68:
Men for the sake of getting a living forget to live.
— Margaret Fuller
69:
Our chief want is someone who will inspire us to be what we know we could be.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
70:
I try all things, I achieve what I can.
-Herman Melville
71:
It matters not where or how far you travel — the farther commonly the worse — but how much alive you are.
-Henry David Thoreau
72:
Once you make a decision, the universe conspires to make it happen.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
73:
Love is a great beautifier.
- Louisa May Alcott
74:
One day’s exposure to mountains is better than a cartload of books.
-John Muir
75:
There is a tendency for things to right themselves.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
76:
Do I contradict myself? Very well, then, I contradict myself; I am large – I contain multitudes.
-Walt Whitman
77:
Give me truth; cheat me by no illusion.
— Margaret Fuller
78:
You cannot do a kindness too soon, for you never know how soon it will be too late.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
79:
Always forgive your enemies; nothing annoys them so much.
-Oscar Wilde
80:
A little kingdom I possess, where thoughts and feelings dwell; And very hard the task I find of governing it well.
- Louisa May Alcott
81:
People that seem so glorious are all show; underneath, they are like everyone else.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
82:
Happiness is like a butterfly; the more you chase it, the more it will elude you. But if you turn your attention to other things, it will come and sit softly on your shoulder.
-Henry David Thoreau
83:
Ignorance is the parent of fear.
-Herman Melville
84:
The only way to have a friend is to be one.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
85:
If I read a book and it makes my whole body so cold no fire can ever warm me, I know that is poetry.
-Emily Dickinson
86:
I am as bad as the worst, but, thank God, I am as good as the best.
-Walt Whitman
87:
An investment in knowledge pays the best interest.

Benjamin Franklin
88:
Anyone who lives within their means suffers from a lack of imagination.
-Oscar Wilde
89:
All goes onward and outward, nothing collapses. And to die is different from what any one supposed, and luckier.
-Walt Whitman
90:
The only person you are destined to become is the person you decide to be.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
91:
He has a right to criticize, who has a heart to help.

Abraham Lincoln
92:
A man thinks that by mouthing hard words he understands hard things.
-Herman Melville
93:
I like the scientific spirit – the holding off, the being sure but not too sure, the willingness to surrender ideas when the evidence is against them: this is ultimately fine – it always keeps the way beyond open – always gives life, thought, affection, the whole man, a chance to try over again after a mistake – after a wrong guess.
-Walt Whitman
94:
A faithful friend is a strong defense; And he that hath found him hath found a treasure.
- Louisa May Alcott
95:
Things do not change; we change.
-Henry David Thoreau
96:
Don’t be too timid and squeamish about your actions. All life is an experiment. The more experiments you make the better.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
97:
One should go to the woods for safety, if for nothing else.
-John Muir
98:
Everything in moderation, including moderation.
-Oscar Wilde
99:
Make your own Bible. Select and collect all the words and sentences that in all your readings have been to you like the blast of a trumpet.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
100:
Real strength never impairs beauty or harmony, but it often bestows it, and in everything imposingly beautiful, strength has much to do with the magic.
-Herman Melville
101:
The powerful play goes on and you may contribute a verse.
-Walt Whitman
102:
The earth laughs in flowers.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
103:
The civilized man is a larger mind but a more imperfect nature than the savage.
— Margaret Fuller
104:
Saying nothing sometimes says the most.
-Emily Dickinson
105:
Some books leave us free and some books make us free.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
106:
Watch and pray, dear, never get tired of trying, and never think it is impossible to conquer your fault.
- Louisa May Alcott
107:
There is no God any more divine than yourself.
-Walt Whitman
108:
A great man is always willing to be little.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
109:
To produce a mighty book, you must choose a mighty theme.
-Herman Melville
110:
Beware the mediocrity that threatens middle age, its limitation of thought and interest, its dullness of fancy, its too external life, and mental thinness.
— Margaret Fuller
111:
Go confidently in the direction of your dreams. Live the life you’ve imagined.
-Henry David Thoreau
112:
You cannot escape the responsibility of tomorrow by evading it today.

Abraham Lincoln
113:
Art is the most intense mode of individualism that the world has known.
-Oscar Wilde
114:
Peace cannot be achieved through violence, it can only be attained through understanding.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
115:
Not all that tempts your wandering eyes
And heedless hearts, is lawful prize;
Nor all that glisters gold.
Thomas Gray
116:
There are days that must happen to you.
-Walt Whitman
117:
We cannot live for ourselves alone. Our lives are connected by a thousand invisible threads, and along these sympathetic fibers, our actions run as causes and return to us as results.
-Herman Melville
118:
Man is not made for society, but society is made for man. No institution can be good which does not tend to improve the individual.
— Margaret Fuller
119:
To live is so startling it leaves little time for anything else.
-Emily Dickinson
120:
And in the end it is not the years in your life that count, it’s the life in your years.

Abraham Lincoln
121:
Good books, like good friends, are few and chosen; the more select, the more enjoyable.
- Louisa May Alcott
122:
Another glorious day, the air as delicious to the lungs as nectar to the tongue.
-John Muir
123:
To me, every hour of the day and night is an unspeakably perfect miracle.
-Walt Whitman
124:
I make myself rich by making my wants few.
-Henry David Thoreau
125:
Nature seems to have poured forth her riches so without calculation, merely to mark the fullness of her joy.
— Margaret Fuller
126:
Write it on your heart that every day is the best day in the year.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
127:
No gains without pains.

Benjamin Franklin
128:
You don't love someone for their looks, or their clothes or their fancy car, but because they sing a song only you can hear.
-Oscar Wilde
129:
Whatever my fate, I'll go to it laughing.
-Herman Melville
130:
We need to hear the excuses men make to themselves for their worthlessness.
— Margaret Fuller
131:
It seems supernatural, but only because it is not understood.
-John Muir
132:
Unless you try to do something beyond what you have already mastered, you will never grow.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
133:
Goodness is the only investment that never fails.
-Henry David Thoreau
134:
Keep good company, read good books, love good things and cultivate soul and body as faithfully as you can.
- Louisa May Alcott
135:
Every man I meet is in some way my superior.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
136:
Beauty is not caused. It is.
-Emily Dickinson
137:
You shall no longer take things at second or third hand, not look through the eyes of the dead, nor feed on the spectres in books. You shall not look through my eyes either, nor take things from me. You shall listen to all sides and filter them from yourself.
-Walt Whitman
138:
People do not seem to realise that their opinion of the world is also a confession of their character.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
139:
Truth is in things, and not in words.
-Herman Melville
140:
I now know all the people worth knowing in America, and I find no intellect comparable to my own.
— Margaret Fuller
141:
In skating over thin ice, our safety is speed.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
142:
Men will believe anything at all provided they are under no obligation to believe it.
Thomas Gray
143:
This world is but a canvas to our imagination.
-Henry David Thoreau
144:
When friendships are real, they are not glass threads or frost work, but the solidest things we can know.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
145:
See how elastic our prejudices grow when once love comes to bend them.
-Herman Melville
146:
I refuse putting from me the best that I am.
-Walt Whitman
147:
Make yourself necessary to somebody.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
148:
I didn’t fail the test, I just found 100 ways to do it wrong.

Benjamin Franklin
149:
Don't try to make me grow up before my time…
- Louisa May
150:
You become what you think about all day long.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
151:
Bring me the sunset in a cup.
-Emily Dickinson
152:
I am not young enough to know everything.
-Oscar Wilde
153:
A right Heart exceeds all.

Benjamin Franklin
154:
I am larger, better than I thought; I did not know I held so much goodness.
-Walt Whitman
155:
What you get by achieving your goals is not as important as what you become by achieving your goals.
-Henry David Thoreau
156:
Character is higher than intellect… A great soul will be strong to live, as well as strong to think.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
157:
There is some danger lest there be no real religion in the heart which craves too much daily sympathy.
— Margaret Fuller
158:
We can complain because rose bushes have thorns, or rejoice because thorn bushes have roses.

Abraham Lincoln
159:
Handle a book as a bee does a flower, extract its sweetness but do not damage it.
-John Muir
160:
The only difference between the saint and the sinner is that every saint has a past, and every sinner has a future.
-Oscar Wilde
161:
I cannot endure to waste anything so precious as autumnal sunshine by staying in the house.
-Nathaniel Hawthorne
162:
Do not go where the path may lead, go instead where there is no path and leave a trail.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
163:
You don't need scores of suitors. You need only one…if he's the right one.
- Louisa May Alcott
164:
There is all the different in the world between paying and being paid.
-Herman Melville
165:
Every man’s happiness is his own responsibility.

Abraham Lincoln
166:
All good things are wild and free.
-Henry David Thoreau
167:
The sum of all known value and respect, I add up in you, whoever you are.
-Walt Whitman
168:
Big jobs usually go to the men who prove their ability to outgrow small ones.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
169:
They hear a voice in every wind, And snatch a fearful joy.
Thomas Gray
170:
Truth is the nursing mother of genius. No man can be absolutely true to himself, eschewing cant, compromise, servile imitation, and complaisance without becoming original.
— Margaret Fuller
171:
Doing well is the result of doing good. That's what capitalism is all about.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
172:
It is to the credit of human nature, that, except where its selfishness is brought into play, it loves more readily than it hates.
-Nathaniel Hawthorne
173:
I have the simplest of tastes. I am always satisfied with the best.
-Oscar Wilde
174:
To know even one life has breathed easier because you have lived. This is to have succeeded.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
175:
I know nothing in the world that has as much power as a word. Sometimes I write one, and I look at it, until it begins to shine.
-Emily Dickinson
176:
A real gentleman is as polite to a little girl as to a woman.
- Louisa May Alcott
177:
Have you learned the lessons only of those who admired you, and were tender with you, and stood aside for you? Have you not learned great lessons from those who braced themselves against you, and disputed passage with you?
-Walt Whitman
178:
For an impenetrable shield, stand inside yourself.
-Henry David Thoreau
179:
Anticipation forward points the view.

Robert Burns
180:
To be yourself in a world that is constantly trying to make you something else is the greatest accomplishment.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
181:
Truth is so rare, it is delightful to tell it.
-Emily Dickinson
182:
At length I fell asleep, with the volume in my hand; and never slept so sound before
-Herman Melville
183:
I am so clever that sometimes I don't understand a single word of what I am saying.
-Oscar Wilde
184:
Do not anticipate trouble, or worry about what may never happen. Keep in the sunlight.

Benjamin Franklin
185:
As to marriage, I think the intercourse of heart and mind may be fully enjoyed without entering into this partnership of daily life.
— Margaret Fuller
186:
Self-trust is the first secret of success.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
187:
It is a good lesson – though it may often be a hard one – for a man… to step aside out of the narrow circle in which his claims are recognized, and to find how utterly devoid of significance, beyond that circle, is all that he achieves, and all he aims at.
-Nathaniel Hawthorne
188:
We turn not older with years but newer every day.
-Emily Dickinson
189:
Nothing astonishes men so much as common sense and plain dealing.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
190:
Suspense is worst than disappointment.

Robert Burns
191:
Most of the luxuries, and many of the so-called comforts of life, are not only not indispensable, but positive hindrances to the elevation of mankind.
-Henry David Thoreau
192:
Enthusiasm is the mother of effort, and without it nothing great was ever achieved.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
193:
Wonderfullest things are ever the unmentionable; deep memories yield no epitaphs
-Herman Melville
194:
Henceforth, I ask not good fortune. I myself am good fortune.
-Walt Whitman
195:
To love oneself is the beginning of a lifelong romance.
-Oscar Wilde
196:
As to posterity, I may ask what has it ever done to oblige me?
Thomas Gray
197:
When we make little sacrifices we like to have them appreciated, at least…
- Louisa May Alcott
198:
Always bear in mind that your own resolution to success is more important than any other thing.

Abraham Lincoln
199:
Words – so innocent and powerless as they are, as standing in a dictionary, how potent for good and evil they become in the hands of one who knows how to combine them.
-Nathaniel Hawthorne
200:
Every man is the builder of a temple called his body.
-Henry David Thoreau
201:
Character is higher than intellect.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
202:
Till I loved I never lived.
-Emily Dickinson
203:
I am not a bit tamed. I too am untranslatable. I sound my barbaric yawp over the roofs of the world.
-Walt Whitman
204:
The good news is that the moment you decide that what you know is more important than what you have been taught to believe, you will have shifted gears in your quest for abundance. Success comes from within, not from without.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
205:
He who reigns within himself and rules passions, desires, and fears is more than a king.
John Milton
206:
Tragedy is always a mistake; and the loneliness of the deepest thinker, the widest lover, ceases to be pathetic to us so soon as the sun is high enough above the mountains.
— Margaret Fuller
207:
There is only one thing in the world worse than being talked about, and that is not being talked about.
-Oscar Wilde
208:
Yes, as everyone knows, meditation and water are wedded for ever.
-Herman Melville
209:
Be worthy love, and love will come...The more you love and trust Him, the nearer you will feel to Him, and the less you will depend on human power and wisdom.
- Louisa May Alcott
210:
Most of the shadows of this life are caused by standing in one’s own sunshine.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
211:
Not all who wander are lost.
-Henry David Thoreau
212:
Without continual growth and progress, such words as improvement, achievement, and success have no meaning.

Benjamin Franklin
213:
The older you get, the older you want to get.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
214:
All merely graceful attributes are usually the most evanescent.
-Nathaniel Hawthorne
216:
What you are comes to you.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
217:
How many persons must there be who cannot worship alone since they are content with so little.
— Margaret Fuller
218:
When I do good, I feel good. When I do bad, I feel bad. That’s my religion.

Abraham Lincoln
219: There are some enterprises in which a careful disorderliness is the true method.
220:
Nothing is impossible to a determined woman.
- Louisa May Alcott
221:
The lovely flowers embarrass me. They make me regret I am not a bee...
-Emily Dickinson
222:
The only reward of virtue is virtue; the only way to have a friend is to be one.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
223:
A man is rich in proportion to the number of things which he can afford to let alone.
-Henry David Thoreau
224:
Sometimes with one I love, I fill myself with rage, for fear I effuse unreturn’d love; But now I think there is no unreturn’d love – the pay is certain, one way or another.
-Walt Whitman
225:
All I have seen teaches me to trust the Creator for all I have not seen.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
226:
There is nothing that making men rich and strong but that which they carry inside of them. True wealth is of the heart, not of the hand.
John Milton
227:
For precocity some great price is always demanded sooner or later in life.
— Margaret Fuller
228:
What you do speaks so loudly that I cannot hear what you say.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
229:
I am out with lanterns, looking for myself.
-Emily Dickinson
230:
There is something truer and more real, than what we can see with the eyes, and touch with the finger.
-Nathaniel Hawthorne
231:
All beauty comes from beautiful blood and a beautiful brain.
-Walt Whitman
232:
A newspaper consists of just the same number of words, whether there be any news in it or not.

Henry Fielding
233:
Every generation laughs at the old fashions, but follows religiously the new.
-Henry David Thoreau
234:
The health of the eye seems to demand a horizon. We are never tired, so long as we can see far enough.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
235:
He that would live in peace & at ease, Must not speak all he knows or judge all he sees.

Benjamin Franklin
236:
In order that she may be able to give her hand with dignity, she must be able to stand alone.
— Margaret Fuller
237:
I have learned that to be with those I like is enough.
-Walt Whitman
238:
...the great floodgates of the wonder-world swung open...
-Herman Melville
239:
Life and love are very precious when both are in full bloom.
- Louisa May Alcott
240:
This time, like all times, is a very good one, if we but know what to do with it.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
241:
Whatever is begun in anger, ends in shame.

Benjamin Franklin
242:
The question is not what you look at, but what you see.
-Henry David Thoreau
243:
To live is the rarest thing in the world. Most people exist, that is all.
-Oscar Wilde
244:
We endeavor to conceal our vices under the disguise of the opposite virtues.

Henry Fielding
245:
It is so true that a woman may be in love with a woman, and a man with a man. It is pleasant to be sure of it, because it is undoubtedly the same love that we shall feel when we are angels...
— Margaret Fuller
246:
Life is a succession of lessons which must be lived to be understood.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
247:
You may delay, but time will not.

Benjamin Franklin
248:
I am a slow walker, but I never walk back.

Abraham Lincoln
249:
Whoever you are, now I place my hand upon you. That you may be my poem. I whisper with my lips close to your ear. I have loved many women and men, but I love none better than you.
-Walt Whitman
250:
Where no hope is left, is left no fear.
John Milton
251:
Cheerfulness can change misfortune into love and friends.
- Louisa May Alcott
252:
Beauty without grace is the hook without the bait.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
253:
Respect for ourselves guides our morals, respect for others guides our manners.
Laurence Sterne
254:
Harmony exists no less in difference than in likeness, if only the same key-note govern both parts.
— Margaret Fuller
255:
Fiction reveals truth that reality obscures.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
256:
Love is not love which alters when it alteration finds.
-William Shakespeare
257:
I would rather sit on a pumpkin, and have it all to myself, than be crowded on a velvet cushion.
-Henry David Thoreau
258:
Before we acquire great power we must acquire wisdom to use it well.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
259:
Good writers will, indeed, do well to imitate the ingenious traveller. . .who always proportions his stay in any place.

Henry Fielding
260:
Happy is the son whose faith in his mother remains unchallenged.
- Louisa May Alcott
261:
Some people are so much sunshine to the square inch.
-Walt Whitman
262:
I take a simple view of life. It is keep your eyes open and get on with it.
Laurence Sterne
263:

— Margaret Fuller
264:
Whatever you are, be a good one.

Abraham Lincoln
266:
When in doubt, don’t.

Benjamin Franklin
267:
All faults may be forgiven of him who has perfect candor.
-Walt Whitman
268:

-Ralph Waldo Emerson
556:
How poor are they that have not patience! What wound did ever heal but by degrees?
-William Shakespeare
557:
Pointing to another world will never stop vice among us; shedding light over this world can alone help us.
-Walt Whitman
558:
All the good of nature is the soul’s, and may be had, if paid for in nature’s lawful coin, that is, by labor which the heart and the head allow.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
559:
Let Greeks be Greeks, and women what they are.
Anne Bradstreet
560:
Art can only be truly art by presenting an adequate outward symbol of some fact in the interior life.
— Margaret Fuller
561:
The reward of a thing well done is having done it.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
562:
Uneasy lies the head that wears the crown.
-William Shakespeare
563:
Let your soul stand cool and composed before a million universes.
-Walt Whitman
564:
The real and lasting victories are those of peace and not of war.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
565:
When you’re good to others, you’re best to yourself.

Benjamin Franklin
566:
The last change in our point of view gives the whole world a pictorial air.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
567:
Life is but a day at most.

Robert Burns
568:
Give every man thy ear, but few thy voice.
-William Shakespeare
569:
To lengthen thy life, lessen thy meals.

Benjamin Franklin
570:
Who you are speaks so loudly, I can't hear what you're saying.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
571:
How strange that nature does not knock, and yet does not intrude!
-Emily Dickinson
572:
Tremble not before the free man, but before the slave who has chains to break.
— Margaret Fuller
573:
Afoot and lighthearted I take the open road, healthy free, the world before me.
-Walt Whitman
574:
Reading makes a full Man, Meditation a profound Man, Discourse a clear Man.

Benjamin Franklin
575:
Our doubts are traitors and make us lose the good we oft might win by fearing to attempt.
-William Shakespeare
576:
Flowers... are a proud assertion that a ray of beauty outvalues all the utilities of the world.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
577:
A true Friend is the best Possession.

Benjamin Franklin
578:
Adopt the pace of nature: her secret is patience.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
579:
Youth is the time of getting, middle age of improving, and old age of spending.
Anne Bradstreet
580:
Next to invention is the power of interpreting invention; next to beauty the power of appreciating beauty.
— Margaret Fuller
581:
There never was a good war or a bad peace.

Benjamin Franklin
582:
Every man has his own courage, and is betrayed because he seeks in himself the courage of other persons.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
583:
We know what we are, but know not what we may be.
-William Shakespeare
584:
Can anything be so elegant as to have few wants, and to serve them one's self?
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
585:
An early-morning walk is a blessing for the whole day.
-Henry David Thoreau
586:
I am satisfied. I see, dance, laugh, sing.
-Walt Whitman
587:
Dare to be honest and fear no labor.

- Robert Burns
588:
It is one of the blessings of old friends is that you can afford to be stupid with them.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
589:
"Now's the day and now's the hour."

- Robert Burns
590:
The poet lights the light and fades away. But the light goes on and on.
-Emily Dickinson
591:
Now I see the secret of making the best person: it is to grow in the open air and to eat and sleep with the earth.
-Walt Whitman
592:
Be not afraid of greatness. Some are born great, some achieve greatness, and others have greatness thrust upon them.
-William Shakespeare
593:
What a difference it makes to come home to a child!
— Margaret Fuller
594:
A man's growth is seen in the successive choirs of his friends.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
595:
Do not be too moral. You may cheat yourself out of much life so. Aim above morality. Be not simply good, be good for something.
-Henry David Thoreau
596:
The first wealth is health.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
597:
The soul of the great musician can only be expressed in music.
— Margaret Fuller
598:
I swear to you, there are divine things more beautiful than words to tell.
-Walt Whitman
599:
No great man ever complains of want of opportunity.
-Ralph Waldo Emerson
